titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

lg.l: But you, with pleasure, own each error past,
And make each day, a Critic on the last.

div.p: Pope.

1. Detained at home great part of the morning. Spent the remainder of it at my Office— Dexter came to town with a Chaise; and I went with him, after dinner to Quincy. The roads extremely rough. Mr: Boylston called at my Office in the morning.

2. Heard Mr: Whitney— His afternoon discourse was an annual sermon— Wrote a letter to my brother Thomas, and made a translation of the first pages of Mr: Luzac’s Oration de Socrate Cive— There is a translation, which will not answer.

3. A Snow-storm of extreme violence arose in the night, and continued through the greatest part of this day, so that I did not attempt to return home— Pass’d the day in the Office— The forenoon, translating from Luzac’s Socrates— The afternoon and evening, reading J. B. Rousseau. Towards night it cleared away.

4. Return’d to Boston this morning in the Stage; with only one companion part of the way. Had a meeting of the directors of Neponset river Bridge, and agreed upon a petition to the General Court;— to alter the place of the Bridge— Mr: Boylston was at my Office— Pass’d the evening at Mr: J. Gore’s, with a large company.— Play’d at Cards, with Mr: Baboock, Mr: M’Lane, and Mr: G. Greene.

5. Went out to Dedham in a Chaise, to attend the Court of Common Pleas which was to sit there; but found upon my arrival that the Court had yesterday been adjourn’d to the 17th: by two Justices; no judge having yet been appointed in stead of Mr: Everett who died a few days since— After sitting about an hour with Mr: Townsend, I return’d to Boston to dinner— Much of the snow had disappeared in the interval. Rain towards Night. Walking home, Mr: Hall overtook me, and came with me. We play’d a couple of games of chess.

6. Mr: Morrill called at my Office— Petition for Incorporation of the Trustees under John Boylston’s Will. We had a violent storm with rain all night, and it rain’d the greater part of this day.— Clear’d in the afternoon, and grew cold— Walk’d in the Mall, and then wrote at my Office most of the Evening.— Louisa Smith who came to town last Saturday, and is with us, went this Evening, with Mrs: Smith to the Assembly.

7. Court of Common-Pleas sat this forenoon; which I attended— Mr: Boylston and Mr: Pitts called upon me. The afternoon I did not leave home— In the Evening, we had a Company of about forty persons, who danc’d, untill about Midnight— I danced myself the whole Evening.

8. Our Company had been gone only a few minutes when there was an alarm of fire; several shops burnt down— At four in the morning, there was a second alarm at the same place; it was soon extinguish’d. Day at my Office— In the afternoon I went out to Quincy with Mr: James Bracket.
9. Day very cold— Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham: who dined with us. Wrote a letter to my brother, with an enclosure— Engaged upon the Socrates;—but could not go through so much as I wish’d.

10. Return’d to Boston early this morning.— Dined with Mr: Quincy— Mr: Dowse, Mr: Dutton, Mr: Wells, and Mr: Vose, Quincy’s classmate were there— In the evening Quincy, Dr: Jackson and myself attended at the Society’s chamber and attempted some chemical experiments— We made some oxygen gas, from manganese; and broke one of our bottles, in the process— Mrs: Adams and the ladies spent the evening at Mrs: C. Millar’s.

11. Court of Common Pleas sitting; and I attended— Had a meeting of the directors of Neponset river bridge— Calls from various persons upon business— In the Evening, Mrs: Adams had a party of ladies at home— Mrs: Codman, Mrs: Otis, Mrs: Smith, Mrs: Gardner, Miss Storer’s, Charlotte Welsh &c.— Hall was at my Office this afternoon.

12. This is the day to which the Legislature of the Commonwealth was adjourned.— I attended at the Senate chamber, both morning and afternoon; but there were not members enough to form a quorum— The house made one in the afternoon— At my Office writing for a couple of hours— In the evening, attended the club at Mr: Emerson’s— Judge Davis also held a District Court in the forenoon; and postponed it to the 26th: for evidence.

13. Attended at the Court of Common Pleas, and in the Senate, who just made out to form a quorum— Sent a joint Committee to inform the Governor, who answered he would meet the two houses to-morrow at 12. o’clock. Voted to chuse at 11. to-morrow morning, a chaplain instead of Dr: Thacher, who died since the last Session. I put Mr: Emerson in nomination— This afternoon I presented a petition from the Directors of the Neponset Bridge, for altering the place where it is to be built— Joint-Committee— Mr: Coffin and Mr: Thompson of the Senate— Presented also the petition of the Trustees and Executor of John Boylston’s Will, to be incorporated, with the overseers of the poor for the town of Boston— Joint Committee— Myself on the part of the Senate— Both houses agreed to have but one session a day; and to injoin upon all the Committees to sit in the afternoon. Went to the Ball this Evening— Danced with Countess Rumford, Mrs: Otis and Mrs: Jonn: Davis— Play’d whist about half an hour with Mr: Crafts, Mr: Cobb and Mr: Joy.— Took Miss Morton home— It was past one in the morning before we got home ourselves— Mrs: Adams, Louisa Smith and Caroline, all went.

14. Attended at the Senate— The Governor made his speech at 12 o’clock— Committed in the Senate, to Mr: Tudor, Dr: Hill and myself to draw up the answer— We agreed that the chairman, Mr: Tudor should draw it up.— At 11. o’clock the chaplain was chosen. The votes were 17.— Mr: Emerson had 10. Mr: Baldwin 6 and Dr: Stillman 1. Mr: Coffin and myself were chosen a Committee to inform Mr: Emerson of his election— Which we did immediately after the Senate rose.— It rain’d and storm’d so much the whole afternoon and evening that I did not leave my house. Our Society was to have met this evening.— Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy with Mr: Welles, and return’d this Evening— Louisa Smith left us this day, and went to spend some days with Mrs: Smith.

15. Attended at the Senate this morning— No object of material consequence was brought before them. met the Committee on the petition for incorporation, of John Boylston’s trustees— They desired me to draw a bill— Mr: P. C. Brooks was at my Office— After dinner, I went with my wife and child, and Caroline, to Quincy— In the evening we saw the blaze of a great fire at Boston.

16. Heard Mr: Whitney. Continued the translation of Luzac’s Oration de Socrate Cive— And to vary the employment with a little pleasantry, translated Fontenelle’s Sonnet of Apollo and Daphne; which I found in La Harpe.— Read part of Milton’s Paradise regained.

17. Mr: Curtis and Mr: Bracket called on me before I left Quincy— We all return’d to Boston this forenoon. I attended at the Senate, but no quorum was formed— Dined at Mr: Jonathan Davis’s; with a small company of Gentlemen— Spent the Evening at home, reading part of Shakespear’s tempest to the Ladies— After we went to bed, and just before midnight, there was an alarm of fire— I went to it, and remained there untill it was subdued— An house, shop and store close upon Winisimet ferry were burnt down— At about half past one in the morning I return’d home.

18. Rose late, and attended the Senate— We have two or three members additional to those who were here last week. The answer to the Governor’s speech, drawn up by Mr: Tudor was reported, adopted, and by the same Committee appointed to draw it up, delivered to him— Several persons called at my Office, after the adjournment— I pass’d the afternoon, and part of the evening there— Call’d at Mr: Brookes’s Office in the afternoon— Mr: James Lloyd brought me a subscription paper for a new bank in this town— I declined subscribing as being a member of the Legislature.
19. There was little business done, and none of consequence in the Senate this day. The afternoon I spent at my Office— Evening at the club at Dr: Kirkland’s.— Henry out this night.

20. Applied to Justice Bourne for a writ— But Henry returned this forenoon. In the Senate little business was transacted, except references to Committees— In the afternoon I went to the Senate chamber, but the Committee which I was to attend had adjourn’d— Spent the evening at my Office, writing— Dined at Mr: W. Crafts’s with a small company of gentlemen.

21. Caroline has been some days unwell— The business in Senate begins to be more important. The applications for Banks and Insurance Companies are commencing— This forenoon an alarm of fire near my own house called me out— It was at Mr: Sumner’s Office; but was extinguish’d before it had done much damage— Dined with Sheriff Allen, and nine or ten Gentlemen— At four in the afternoon I attended at Faneuil Hall; at a meeting of the town’s Committee for negotiating with the Legislature for their right in the old State-House— We agreed upon an alternative of two proposals to make them, and chose a Sub-committee to treat with the Committee from the General Court— At 6. I met with the Committee of both houses upon two applications for new Banks; one in Boston, and one at Newbury-Port— Heard them and their Counsel until 9 o’clock— Mr: Parsons attended— I passed the remainder of the evening with the Society for the Study of Natural Philosophy; from whose last two meetings I had been detained— Sold my father’s six per Cents and deferr’d Stock, and purchased for him some shares in the fire and marine insurance Company.

22. No business of material consequence in the Senate this forenoon— Adjourned to 11. o’clock Monday Morning.— At one o’clock I went to Whitcomb’s, where his child, a daughter, born the 23d: of last month, was baptized by Dr: Parker, by the name of Catherine Louisa— Mrs: Adams and myself stood as sponsors.— Spent the afternoon, and principal part of the Evening at my Office, writing.

23. Heard Mr: Allen this morning, and Mr: Emerson in the afternoon— After the service the members of the Society were detained to vote for joining in a petition with the Brattle-Street church, for a removal of the restraint limiting the power of taxation upon pews to two shillings by the week. The standing Committee were chosen agents for the purpose— Walk’d in the Mall towards evening. Call’d at Mr: Babcock’s, but did not find him at home— At Mr: Smith’s and shew’d him the Act of Incorporation I have drawn up for the Trustees of the Boylston donations— Call’d at the post-office— Rest of the Evening at home— Mr: Hall, came with Mr: B. Greene junr: to my house this morning; and with Mr: John Welles again at noon; upon the business of a new petition for an Insurance Company.— Just before dinner, Caroline came down from her chamber, and called me to look at the hearth, from the corners of which smoke was continually issuing— I had the stones and bricks of the hearth immediately taken up, and found a large beam crossing under the hearth, on fire, and burnt more than half through. We extinguished it immediately; and I sent for a mason to come to-morrow and alter the hearth.

24. Had our chimnies alter’d— Mrs: Adams and Caroline spent the Evening at Miss Gray’s; but I was so much engaged in business that I could not go. All the forenoon in the Senate; the serious business is just commencing. Reported from the Committee on petition of J. Boylston’s Trustees; that they have leave to bring in a bill. Report accepted, and the bill read the first time— Presented the petition for a new Insurance Company.— Read and Committed— The Attorney General and Mr: J. Joy gave Mr: Tudor and me a petition from the President and Directors of the Middlesex Canal Company, with a bill drawn up to be presented— Moved for a Committee to enquire into the expediency of the Commonwealth’s subscribing and paying in 200,000 Dollars more to the Union Bank—and to provide for the means— Committee raised— Mr: Coffin moved for a Committee to consider the expediency of making application to the Congress of Union for the liberty to transfer part of their Stock in the funds, to pay off the State debt— Committee raised— At 1/2 past 3 p.m. met the Committee raised to consider the expediency of prohibiting horse-racing— Agreed Mr: Bidwell should draw up a bill— At 4. o’clock met the Committee on the bill pass’d by the house for incorporating a new Marine Insurance Company.— Mr: S. P. Gardner and Mr: N. Lee came before the Committee and argued their cause— The Committee agreed to many alterations in the bill, which I am to draw up and report to morrow— We were kept untill almost 8 o’clock, and I pass’d the remainder of the Evening at home.

25. Drew up this morning the alterations proposed in the Bill for establishing a new Insurance Company, for the consideration of the Committee— Other petitions of the same kind were presented and committed. A good deal of private business was dispatched, but none of public nature. Met at 1/2 past three the Committee on the expediency of publishing the private Statutes, and agreed upon a report— At four the Committee on the Insurance bill met and discussed the alterations
I had drawn up— They directed me to prepare a new copy of them, as finally agreed upon to be reported to-morrow— It was almost 8 in the evening when we adjourned— I went to my Office, and wrote untill 9.

26. Mr: Bracket called on me to attend the District Court for him, which I did— The business was adjourned over untill the day after to-morrow— Attended at the Senate— Our alterations of the Insurance Company bill were reported; but other business engaged the time and the consideration of them was postponed untill to’morrow morning, at 10. There was a meeting of the Academy which I could attend only for a few minutes— My father, Dr: Tufts and Mr: Pickman dined with us— Caroline, confined to her chamber— In the afternoon I attended the Committees of the town of Boston and of the General Court relative to the Old State House— We made our proposals for the consideration of the Committee from the Legislature, but came to no conclusion—The Committee on the proposed subscription to the Banks met and after some conversation agreed to notify the Directors of the Union Bank, and meet again to-morrow at 4. o’clock— The Committee on the application for a Bank at Northampton met at 6 and heard the applicants and their Counsel— Between 7 and 8 we adjourned. Remainder of the evening at the club at Mr: Quincy’s— Mr: Stedman there— Mr: Emerson told me I was reported to be in opposition to the new Insurance Company; and that I had no conception how unpopular my opposition is— Had some conversation with J. Welles.

27. The Insurance Company bill was debated at the second reading, and the amendment proposed by the Committee to provide for a general subscription, provided for rejected by a large majority— The Senate then adjourned without discussing the remainder of the bill— At half past twelve, the Senate attended in the Council Chamber, at a meeting of the Overseers of Harvard College, where by an unanimous vote they concurred in the nomination of John Davis, as a member of the Corporation— In the afternoon at 1/2 past 3. I met the joint Committee on the petition of Jonathan Simpson— He appeared and produced his note— But the Committee came to no determination upon the subject— At 4. Met with the Joint Committee, and the Directors of the Union-Bank, on the subject of a subscription to that Bank— Conversed with them, and afterwards in Committee, untill between 7. and 8 in the evening; then adjourned without deciding on a report— Rest of the Evening at my Office, writing.

28. Part of the morning I was engaged in the Senate, and the remainder in the Admiralty Court, before Judge Davis, on Captain Bracket’s business. The libel against his vessel was discharg’d— An Act past both houses to postpone the sitting of the Supreme Court in the County of Suffolk, from the second to the last Tuesday in February, and for the County of Norfolk from next week untill the last Tuesday in March. The bill for prohibiting horse-races was read the first time; and one or two turn-pike bills— I dined at Mr: John Welles’s with a company of fifteen Gentlemen— Spent the Evening with the Society, where I read a synopsis of the 9th: 10th: and 11th: chapters of Lavoisier— Our meeting was small.— Mrs: Adams and Caroline spent the evening at Mrs: Gardner Greene’s, with a very large company. I was there a few minutes at the close of the evening.

29. A vote was pass’d in Senate this forenoon to concur with the house in raising a Committee for an address to remove P. D. Sargent andVinall from the offices of Justices of the Sessions and Common Pleas in the County of Hancock— It was an impeachable offence which occasioned this measure— And I thought the mode of proceeding by Address, especially without giving the parties an opportunity to be heard, was improper. The numbers on taking the vote were 13 and 10— After the adjournment, Mr: Boylston called at my Office. I went out to Quincy, early after dinner, in the Chaise.
30. Heard Mr: Ware—who dined with us. It snow’d part of the day, and then turn’d to rain— In the evening it grew cold again— Spent the principal part of the day at the Office, reading and writing.

31. Return’d to Boston this morning— Louisa Smith came into town likewise; and we took Susan to her school, at Milton— Town-meeting called to reconsider a vote pass’d last week for petitioning the legislature for a Law, that all buildings more than ten feet high, should henceforth be erected entirely of brick— The vote was confirmed— I did not get to town soon enough to attend the meeting— Nor untill the Senate had adjourned— This afternoon I attended a couple of hours at the Committee Room, on the petition from the two Churches in Boston— Spent the Evening at my Office— Caroline went this afternoon to Roxbury to spend some days with Mrs: Dexter.

Day— Rise irregularly from 6 to 8 o’clock. Read or write at home untill 1/2 past nine. Breakfast— Attend the Senate untill two— Return to Dinner— At 1/2 past 3 again attend the Committees untill 7, 8, & 9. in the evening— When I have leisure in the afternoon or evening, I pass it at my Office, writing. But I continue generally to spend two evenings in the week at Quincy, one at Club, one at the Society, and upon an average, one at the Ball, or in Company— All my time is employed.
